head.title: Technology Shares Lift Nasdaq, but Wave Stops There

hedline.hl1: Technology Shares Lift Nasdaq, but Wave Stops There

abstract.p: Nasdaq composite index climbs 75.27 points, or 1.8 percent, to 4,174.86; Dow Jones industrial average edges up 5.30 points, or 0.05 percent, to 10,788.71; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 2.92 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,495.84; graph; chart (M)

block.p: Strong quarterly reports from several companies touched off fresh buying in technology stocks yesterday, lifting the Nasdaq composite index to a second consecutive solid gain as the rest of the market mostly languished.

The Nasdaq, which climbed 75.27 points, or 1.8 percent, to 4,174.86, moved more solidly into positive territory for the year. With a gain of 2.6 percent, it has now outperformed the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which is up 1.8 percent this year. Nasdaq has surged 31.9 percent since May 23, when its springtime plunge -- a drop of 37.3 percent from its March peak -- hit bottom.

Strong quarterly reports from several companies touched off fresh buying in technology stocks yesterday, lifting the Nasdaq composite index to a second consecutive solid gain as the rest of the market mostly languished.

The Nasdaq, which climbed 75.27 points, or 1.8 percent, to 4,174.86, moved more solidly into positive territory for the year. With a gain of 2.6 percent, it has now outperformed the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which is up 1.8 percent this year. Nasdaq has surged 31.9 percent since May 23, when its springtime plunge -- a drop of 37.3 percent from its March peak -- hit bottom.

''The earnings announcements are giving people confidence'' that Internet and other high-technology companies will sustain profit growth, said Michael D. Jamison, managing director at Brandywine Asset Management in Wilmington, Del.

Ariba, for example, jumped 27 11/16, to 13 13/16, after issuing its quarterly report, and Applied Micro Circuits, which reported late Wednesday, added 28 1/16, to 153 1/2. Motorola, a New York Stock Exchange company that also posted results on Wednesday, gained 3 3/4, to 39 1/4, as the second most actively traded stock of the day, after Cisco Systems, which rose 1 3/8, to 65 1/4.
But there was little enthusiasm for other than technology shares.

The S.& P. 500 rose 2.92 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,495.84. The biggest upward force was WorldCom, which rose 3 7/16, to 47 15/16, after its merger with Sprint was officially ended. Pfizer was the biggest drag, falling 1 7/8, to 46 1/8.
The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 5.30 points, or 0.05 percent, to 10,788.71, its fifth consecutive rise, but is still down 6.16 percent for the year.
Drug stocks were battered again as Washington appeared to move closer to adding prescriptions to Medicare coverage. Investors fear that will bring price limitations.
Schering-Plough and Merck each lost more than 4 points, and Bristol-Myers Squibb dropped more than 3.

Investors were also bracing for government reports today on producer prices, retail sales and industrial output for June, and for a reading on consumer sentiment by the University of Michigan. Evidence that the pace of inflation has become more than a creep or that the economy is not slowing markedly would undermine an assumption that the Federal Reserve's yearlong raising of short-term interest is near an end.

''The conclusion that most people have is that the Fed is finished,'' said Robert Bloom, president of Friends, Ivory & Sime, a money manager. But he said he disagreed, citing, among other things, a still-taut job market in which job growth is slowing because the pool of potential workers is drying up, not because demand for them has slackened.
(By Bloomberg News) -- Bond prices rose yesterday after a report showed an increase in jobless claims and the Federal Reserve bought Treasuries in two rounds of purchases.

The price of the 10-year Treasury note rose 1 8/32, to 103 21/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.99 percent from 6.07 percent on Wednesday. The 30-year Treasury bond increased 2 9/32, to 106 4/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.82 percent from 5.88 percent on Wednesday.
